author: Simon Robb for Metro.co.uk
title: Children are ‘getting high by sniffing burning wheelie bins’
text:
There’s allegedly a new drug craze happening across Britain (Picture: Getty/Metro.co.uk/Myles Goode) Children are torching wheelie bins to get high from the burning fumes in the weirdest drug craze yet, it has been claimed 
It is believed that certain waste bins, depending on the colour of the plastic, create toxic fumes which get users stoned, a waste management company has claimed.
People who voted leave may be hardest hit by Brexit And officials at the firm believe it is happening all over Britain with reported cases up 100% in the last few months, reports Bedford Today .
‘We’ve seen reports from across the country in recent weeks, and they’re all the same,’ said Mark Hall, of waste firm businesswaste.co.uk.
‘Idiots stealing wheeled bins from outside homes and businesses, taking them to waste ground or parks, and torching them for whatever kicks they can derive.’
Burning bins release toxic fumes that can cause serious damage to your health (Picture: Getty Images) So what is getting them high?
London terror attacker probed over remote-controlled car bomb plot on army base Wheelie bins are made from high density polyethylene, and when set alight it releases a mixture of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide.
The gases starve the brain of oxygen giving a high, but only lasts for a short time.
And anti-solvent abuse charities believe breathing in the fumes cause more damage to your health than sniffing glue or petrol.
The fumes released allegedly depend on the colour of the bin (Picture: Getty Images) Mr Hall admitted that some incidents are most likely arson, but claimed police had told him others are down to ‘drug-related kicks’.
The bizarre craze is believed to have started in South Yorkshire back in 2007, where around 40 bins reportedly went up in smoke in a matter of months.
Eritrean migrants pulled from lorry in Cambridgeshire But Mr Hall warned if an aerosol can is in the bin it could cause a fatal explosion.
‘And bins stolen from business premises could contain just about anything that can cause fatal injury to the unwary,’ he added.
PC Jonathan Reed, of South Yorkshire Police, told the newspaper: ‘The health and safety implications are terrible. It is only a matter of time before someone harms themselves.’
